I’m sure you’ve been busy with the holiday rush but if you have extra time this Saturday and are local, stop by our booth at Rosales Nursery in Long Beach 💚 Large plants at an affordable price will be there! 

Lots of vendors, collectors, and plant enthusiasts will be there. Bring a cutting or two, a pot of your extra plant, or just your joyous self to the meet! You can trade plants and make friends! This is an amazing community and I truly believe you will enjoy it!

If you plan on going and have requests, you can email us at support@unsolicitedplanttalks.com and prepay so all you have to do is show up and not worry about your plants! We will secure it for you 💚

If you’re not into plants, that’s okay too! We’re all good people who just want to make the world a bit of a better place. We can’t promise we won’t talk about plants though! 😆 

Let me know if you guys are coming and comment down below what you’re hoping to snag!

One of the easiest, and most successful rescue methods for us at UPT is chop ✂️ & prop 🌱
When doing this, make sure you chop all the dead vines from the plant. Then, look for arial roots on the dying vines and use those for your props 👍🏻 For this species, we used our standard husk/coir mix for the pots.
We believe this plant is a lacunosa x obscura seedling

Sometimes, we tend to forget that even though some of these species are widely available and easily obtainable, they are still stunning on their own. During the pandemic, many of us (yes, me too!) were panic buying and had FOMO with the RARE, UNCOMMON, and EXPENSIVE ones. We just went.. BUY! BUY! BUY! We literally were so crazy about this hobby because we were cooped in. Now that it’s calmed down a bit, many of us are finally slowing down to really appreciate every single one of them, without the price tag or the rarity looming over them. I’m not saying we never appreciated these guys, we just appreciate them more now 💚

This specific one was controversial for a bit as it was widely available to many (Big box stores carried them) but were labeled differently. We now know that the proper name is Hoya sp. aff. burtoniae! There’s a variegated version that is widely sought after (and I can’t blame you! It’s gorgeous 😍) but due to the speed of growth, it’s a bit harder to find a good size one at the moment. If you’re able to get a hold of the regular one, don’t hesitate. It’s soo beautiful 🤩 

#hoyaspaffburtoniae

All of our Hoya latifolia clones have been loving this time of the year. Here’s Hoya latifolia (Sulawesi GPS8867) rocking sooo many flowers 🌸 at once! None of the flowers are open yet so there’s a possibility most of them will open at the same time. 

Did you know, there are several clones of H. latifolia readily available in the market at the moment? Here are some of them -

Hoya latifolia (used to be called Dinner Plate Hoya)
Hoya latifolia (fka macrophylla)
Hoya latifolia ‘Pot of Gold’
Hoya latifolia ‘Bai Bua’
Hoya latifolia (gps8867)
Hoya latifolia (Sarawak)
Hoya latifolia (clandestina)
Hoya latifolia (polystachya)
and many more!

How many latifolia clones do you have in your collection and which one(s) are your favorites?

Plant parents, I have some exciting news for you! I'll be at the Texas Rare Plant Show this March 26 and I can't wait to share with you some secrets about how I keep our plants healthy!

I'll let you in on a little secret even before the show. I use coco husks to make sure that our plants are always hydrated and healthy. We get a lot of questions about coco husk:  what does this substrate actually do for the plants? How does it affect other care, like watering, or fertilizing?

If you're looking for the answer, it's on our blog. Make sure to read it and we can talk more about it on March 26! See you there!

Have you seen this on your plants lately? I sure did! These marks might be new to some hoya owners, but they are actually signs of cold damage. I found these on our Hoya plants after the first wave of the cold weather in California (we got SNOW?!) and now we're working hard to repair the damage that's been done. Have you guys been seeing similar effects? 

Hoya varieties originate in many locations around the world, so some varieties can tolerate cold better than others. Be on the lookout for damage like this, and move your plant to a warmer location if you start to see it! 

#plants #plantlover #plantdamage #coldweather #UnsolicitedPlantTalks #UPTCollection #plantparentcommunity #urbanjungle #careforplants #houseplantsofinstagram #hoya #hoyaplants

Hey there! Have you heard of Hoya EPC1002? This isn’t new in circulation but might be new to many of you. This hybrid (Hoya vittelina x Hoya finlaysonii) originally came from Epiphytica Garden in Thailand. There is a confusion about this plant online. If you do a quick search on google, you’ll find different looking hoyas (guilty here!) and you might find yourself scratching your head trying to figure out which one is which! But don’t worry! I already did the leg work for all of us 💚

Jakk (the owner of Epiphytica) is a good friend of mine. When I was finally ready to cultivate this clone (This specific clone is from a dear friend of mine @pnw_hoya_collective_ who got it from Ric Moreira), I figured making sure of the name of this cultivar is very important before releasing. After tracing and talking to them, I was able to confirm the name from Jakk himself. 

So today, I have some ready to go to new homes! If you’re interested, they are now available on our website so make sure to grab one as we don’t have very many available of this one! 🙌🏼

Have you seen these in your plants? If yes, these are some signs your plant may have too much or too little water. 

If you're seeing leaves like this and your substrate is too wet, take more time between watering. Otherwise, you may need to increase your watering schedule, and look at the light, heat, and humidity in your plant's environment. Make sure to give your plants the right amount of love and this will be resolved in no time!

Fun fact: The color of Hoya flowers can change under bright light, just like some of the leaves which can take on different hues in such environments! Here's an example: The accompanying photo features two blooming peduncles from the same Hoya EPC301 plant. One of these peduncles was exposed to bright light while the other was hidden away behind other plant foliage, effectively shaded from the bright light. As you can see from the picture, the exposed peduncle has taken on a pink hue (which deepens with increased exposure), whereas the shaded one remains white. Additionally, the leaf next to the pink flower has also been sunstressed.

I first observed this phenomenon with Hoya 'Rebecca'. When I added one of these plants to my collection, I propagated another pot and placed it in a bright environment to see how it would react. Not only did the plant's leaves develop a vibrant red coloration, it also produced pink flowers! Conversely, the plant grown in a shaded area produced white blooms. Interestingly, I didn't detect any differences in scent.

As you may already know, brighter environments encourage more frequent blooming in Hoyas, producing more flowers in the process. Ultimately, there's no one correct way to grow these plants - it all comes down to your preferences. Do you wish to have bigger and darker leaves? Perhaps you would prefer to give the plants less light. On the other hand, if you want a colorful plant that blooms abundantly, then more light is in order. If you can't decide, why not propagate another pot and grow them separately in two different environments? This way, you can enjoy the best of both worlds!

Hey plant peep!

I cannot wait to share with you the Hoya dasyantha that I spotted in the greenhouse this morning - it's a real gem! I mean, have you seen all the white fuzzy blooms it's covered in? Talk about inviting! I think it's definitely ready for a new loving home, and I hope one of you lucky green thumbs can make that happen! 

Keep in mind, this Hoya is currently in a 4in pot, so it's time for an up potting this growing season. As an epiphytic plant, it doesn't technically need a potting medium, but let's be real - it's hard to pull off at home. The good news is that this plant will thrive in a small pot as long as it gets the water it needs, so no worries there. As the plant grows, it'll ask for more water, which is why most Hoya growers end up giving their plants a bigger pot. Just remember, the bigger the plant, the more it drinks! 

If this Hoya is calling your name, it's now available on our site! But act fast - there's only one in stock and it won't last long!

Hello there on this delightful Sunday! Today, let's turn our attention to the remarkable Hoya patcharawalai 023, also known as Hoya #icensis. Originating from the beautiful Patcharawalai Garden in Thailand, this plant has captured my heart and I'm thrilled to share its unique qualities with you.

One of the aspects that make this Hoya so special is its ease of care and rapid growth. It's truly a low-maintenance gem. In fact, it has quickly become one of my personal favorites! Under low light conditions, its leaves can grow impressively large, while a bright shaded environment will enhance the striking dark margin on the leaves. For those who appreciate a splash of vibrant colors, exposing it to direct bright light will result in truly mesmerizing leaf coloration.

Now, let's talk about the flowers, which are the epitome of beauty. Pictured flower depicts delicate white corollas adorned with a charming pink corona. You may be familiar with the idea that flowering Hoyas require ample water, humidity, and appropriate lighting. However, here's the exciting part: Hoya patcharawalai 023 doesn't demand high humidity to thrive! While humidity certainly aids its growth, it is not a necessity for maintaining this stunning plant in your household. And when it comes to blooming, this Hoya is wonderfully consistent. It can produce magnificent blooms not only in bright environments but also in lower light settings. Just ensure it has access to some source of light, avoiding dark corners, and it will reward you with its captivating blossoms, all while requiring minimal lighting.

Considering all these remarkable attributes, I think it’s a must have in anyone’s collection. So what do you think? Are you ready to add one to yours? 

PS - there’s a silver form 😱

#hoyapatcharawalai023

The rule of thumb 👍 is that we keep the medium moist to ensure that the roots remain active. Hoyas are forgiving plants especially when grown in a controlled or humid environment. They can tolerate it if you occasionally forget to water or let the medium dry a little.  However, it is important to take into consideration the medium you use when propagating.

⚠️ TRIGGER WARNING ⚠️ 

This is the reason why I prefer obtaining our stock plants from another collector within the United States. Although it may involve additional costs, it ensures the acquisition of high-quality plants.

I am not criticizing the practice of importing plants; I have personally engaged in it numerous times in the past, and the outcomes are not always as described. However, importing carries significant risks. In most cases, the exporters are not at fault; rather, it is the inherent risk associated with importing due to the lack of control over carriers and the less-than-ideal conditions at inspection stations. Unfortunately, you cannot file a claim against carriers since they do not provide coverage for live plants. Ultimately, it is up to the exporter to decide whether they will replace the plants or not. Importing can indeed be a great success, but it is important to recognize the reality of these challenges.

Moreover, the price may not always justify the endeavor. With the surge in popularity of houseplants, many overseas sellers have significantly raised their prices. Therefore, I only consider importing when a particular species or cultivar is unavailable locally.

I’m only posting this to show the other side of importing not many people know about. Now that you have this information, you can make a better decision whether it is for you or not. 

Okay, time to rehab now…. See y’all later!

🔼Hoya manipurensis🔼

Let's dive into the beauty of this plant! It showcases these striking triangle-shaped foliage, a rarity among Hoyas. While it's not the easiest to cultivate, it's not overly challenging either. Like typical Hoyas, it requires a well-draining medium, but my main hurdle was avoiding overwatering to prevent root rot, even in a coco husk medium.

This plant thrives in warmth, as I learned during its first winter experience in a greenhouse. The cold didn't suit it well, causing yellowing and leaf loss. However, when placed in a warm greenhouse during spring, it flourished! While I adore sunstressing my plants, with this one, I've found that it looks even more captivating with its lush dark green foliage. It's a delightful contrast to its usual sunstressed appearance, and I've come to appreciate the rich, vibrant green hues that it displays.

Speaking of humidity, it seems to adore it! While not too sensitive to low humidity, providing additional humidity was a great bonus for this plant. Once I got the hang of its preferences, I started propagating it, and now we have stocks of Hoya manupurensis! The young leaves may not fully display the triangle shape yet, but as the plant matures, they'll develop into those cute, distinct leaves.

This Hoya isn't for the faint of heart, but the effort is entirely worthwhile and incredibly rewarding! So, don't hesitate to give it a try and enjoy the satisfaction of watching it thrive! 🌿😊

Did you know there’s a variegated variety of this one? Well, that’s for another post!

#hoyamanipurensis

Introducing another curated Hoya cultivar from our greenhouses!

Hoya 'Mayumi' (UPT002) is a seed-grown variety derived from an open-pollinated Hoya 'Noelle' hailing from Puerto Rico. Among a batch of seeds from the same pod, we carefully selected what we believed to be the most exquisite and easily manageable plant. Given that our previous cultivar was named after our beloved Akita dog, Maliksi, we felt it fitting to name this one after our other dear companion, Mayumi, a Shiba Inu. In Tagalog, Mayumi translates to tender, delicate, refined in manners, humble, and modest.

In terms of care, Hoya 'Mayumi' (UPT002) is a rapid grower with medium-sized leaves. It thrives in our warm environment and appears to tolerate lower humidity well. Depending on your preference, you can grow it under direct light to bring out the beautiful colors on its leaves or under low light to achieve deep, dark green foliage.

Tomorrow, during the drop, a limited number will be available, but the listing is already live! Remember to bookmark it, so you have the chance to grab one before they sell out completely!

Can I tell you a secret? I love being well known in this industry for having some of the healthiest hoyas out there. It's a point of pride! 🥰
However, I don't want to keep all my secrets to myself. After all, your hoya should live a long and happy life after it leaves the greenhouse! That's why I share care tips and secrets here, so you can steal them and grow your own indoor jungles to new levels of lush beauty. 🌱
Substrate is one of the biggest consistent qualities that our plants have, from propagation through shipping. We start and mature all our plants in a specific blend of coco husk and coco coir that allows for ideal moisture AND aeration, so we avoid root rot while allowing roots to drink.
You might need to make some adjustments on our recipe, depending on how wet or dry your environment is. However, we love coco husk and coir for their ability to control moisture, and their low nutrition content - meaning we get to feed our hoyas exactly what they need to thrive. 
Got more questions about coco husk, watering, or fertilizing? Check out our blog post (link in bio)

Hoya mirabilis (clone B) has started blooming in our greenhouse, and I just can't get enough of this species. What's not to love? It grows so quickly for us! Some people might call them slow growers, but I think we've got so many other plants catching our eye that this one seems to grow in a flash💨 .

But it's not just about the growth; there's something special about the leaves of this plant. They have this incredible sheen texture, and their shape? Skinny and pointy, adding an air of elegance that I just adore. If you're a fan of wider leaves, don't worry, clone A keeps that graceful look but offers a broader leaf. Either way, you're in for a treat with this species!

Now, let's talk flowers 🌸 . They're pretty big, especially when you put them next to Hoya lacunosa, a close relative. I mean, these flowers are a lot bigger, and I really mean a lot!

So, go ahead and take a look at these flower photos. I snapped them just before they reflexed, and they're just absolutely stunning! You won't be disappointed. We also have them on our website so if you need one, feel free to grab one!

Did you know?

The term “spartioides” comes from the Greek word “σπάρτος” (spartos) which means “broom” or “broom-like plant.” In taxonomy, “-oides” indicates similarity or resemblance to the genus or species it modifies. So, “spartioides” describes plants or species with characteristics resembling or related to the broom plant (genus Spartium) or broom-like features.

Happy shopping and discovering! 😊

Ever met the enchanting Hoya wallichii ssp. Tenebrosa (SLM02)? Its flowers, shaped like expansive bells, hide a secret maroon color inside with deep dark coronas. And guess what? They come alive mostly at nighttime and can stick around for a few nights in a row. This Hoya, with its dainty thin leaves, not only grows super fast but is also a breeze to care for. It loves a good shady spot, and if you've got high humidity, it'll be over the moon. But don't worry if it's a bit dry where you are; this Hoya's got your back. And about watering, they're a tad thirsty more often due to their thin leaves. But, a heads-up: they aren't fans of too much water. The key? A well-draining, breezy medium. If that sounds like a puzzle, a simple mix of coco husk and coco coir will do the magic!

Ready to add one to your collection? Good news! Our plants are feeling generous and are a tad bigger than our stock photos right now. So, expect a lush buddy in your mail soon! 🌿

Hey Hoya lovers! Buckle up, because our escapade with the Hoya kanyakumariana was more plot-twist-filled novella than plant tale. From the get-go of considering a leafy breakup, we sensed this would be one for the storybooks 📚 .

Let’s spill the 🍵 : We’ve loved this plant longer than some of our favorite Netflix series. Last winter, she didn’t just grow, she glowed. Managed a bloom? Check. Realized she’s a winter babe? Double-check, especially after surviving what felt like a Game of Thrones winter in California. Then summer 🌞 strolled in, flipping the script. Yellowing leaves had us wondering if she was just throwing some seasonal shade or really struggling. With sturdy roots and stems flexing strength, those leaves still decided to bail on us. Major drama, right? Enter @craftiebee3 , our plant savior, trying everything short of plant CPR. Dug up some ancestral intel – turns out, it hails from Kanyakumari in India, where it’s as warm as our last vacation spot. Even Doug from Vermont Hoya says it’s simpler than a Sunday crossword. We were all in… until it was time for the final curtain.

Yesterday, we gave it a send-off worthy of a diva. It had its moments (and trust us, there were MANY 😂). On the bright side, we’ve got cuttings—so here’s hoping our little Hoya soap opera sees another season!

Had your own Hoya highs and lows? Drop your plant-tales below!

🌱 Mastering Hoya latifolia Propagation! 🌱

Venturing into the world of Hoya latifolia propagation? While those woody stems might seem daunting, with a sprinkle of patience and the right touch, you can achieve propagation success! 🌿✨

💡 Top Tips:

1. Score the stem lightly and dip into rooting powder for more root emergence. But remember, use this method judiciously to avoid unwanted infections.

2. Trim down the leaf size on your cutting. This helps the plant channel its energy towards rooting rather than leaf sustenance.

🌿 Unveiling the Hoya lacunosa (krohniana silver): A glance into the intriguing world of partially silver leaves, a signature trait of this cultivar. ✨🍃
Amid the pandemic's whirlwind, this unique plant sparked debates in the community. As collectors flourished, uncertainties arose about its rightful name due to mislabels floating around. A dialogue ignited, with no clear end in sight. Some stood by "Hoya krohniana," while we embraced "Hoya lacunosa (krohniana)" for its accurate representation. Our choice reflects its lacunosa heritage, with 'krohniana' in parentheses, aiding buyers in selecting their clone amidst the lacunosa abundance.
You're welcome to use "Hoya krohniana" if it resonates. Today, both monikers find a home in describing this beauty. 🌸🪴 .

Did you know that the way you orient a cutting can influence whether it survives? 🌱 It's all about the science of apical dominance!
ㅤ
I'm using a Hoya latifolia (Sarawak) to demonstrate here, but this rule applies to all my props.
ㅤ
The top part of many plants actually "communicates" with the lower branches to control growth. 🌿 Get it wrong, and you could be messing with Mother Nature's plan for your plant to root and thrive. Especially if you're planting Hoyas, which are strong believers in apical dominance! 🍃
ㅤ

When it comes to propagating Hoya latifolia (Sarawak), the devil is in the details. The first crucial step is the cut, and for that, I swear by curved shears. Their thin blades are perfect for navigating the intricate foliage, ensuring a clean and precise cut. But before those shears touch the plant, they're sprayed with either freshly mixed Physan20 or 99% isopropyl alcohol. This sterilization step is non-negotiable; it's our safeguard against transferring any fungal infections or diseases from previous plant projects.

Now, here's a pro tip: when dealing with a mature Hoya latifolia in a 12-inch pot, resist the urge to cut all the way down to the base. Doing so risks waterlogging and potential root rot, not to mention it can temporarily stunt the plant's growth as it adjusts to its new, less leafy self. So, if you're looking to propagate like a pro, these are the nuances that make all the difference. Head over to our website for more in-depth tips and tricks on plant care and propagation. Trust us, your plants will thank you!

#hoyalatifoliasarawak

Have We Forgotten About Hoya sp. Rangsan?
In the hustle and bustle of exploring new and exotic Hoya species, it's easy to overlook some of the classics. One such gem is Hoya sp. Rangsan, a cultivar that deserves a spotlight for its ease of growth and quick blooming nature.
ㅤ
Easy to Root and Grow 🌱
We grow this cultivar in a coco husk / coco coir combination with ease. It surely is an easy one to root and grow. This also isn't too hard to flower as you can encourage it to bloom with plenty of light and water. Fertilizing will also be beneficial, so if you are able, make sure to add that to your routine as well!
ㅤ
Splashy Leaves for Aesthetic Appeal 🍃
The plant is primarily grown for its splashy leaves, adding an aesthetic appeal to your indoor garden. While there is limited information about its origins, it is believed to hail from Rangsang, Indonesia.
ㅤ
A Future Classic? 🌟
There's a movement in the Hoya world to lump many previously separate species into single species with different clones based on locations. Hoya sp. Rangsan might eventually be lumped in with Hoya latifolia, as its flowers are identical to those of macrophylla and polystachya, which are now all called Hoya latifolia.
ㅤ
Why Choose Hoya sp. Rangsan?
Easy to Root and Grow: Ideal for beginners or those who don't want to spend too much time on plant care.
Aesthetic Appeal: The splashy leaves make it a decorative addition to any space.
So, have we rekindled your interest in Hoya sp. Rangsan? 🌿
ㅤ
Would you like to know more about this plant or perhaps explore other Hoya species? Feel free to ask!
ㅤ

I acquired this specific cultivar through a cherished colleague, Ara (@shopplantasmic ). The captivating narrative surrounding this particular variety is one of serendipity; it was erroneously sold to her as Hoya 'Svetlana'. To a novice Hoya colectors, the similarities between the two might appear striking. However, having cultivated both varieties in our specialized greenhouses, I can confirm their individual uniqueness.
ㅤ
It's worth noting that both Hoya types possess somewhat succulent leaves that culminate in a pointed tip. Yet, this specific cultivar manifests its own set of exceptional traits. For instance, when grown in low-light conditions, the leaves tend to be more slender. Conversely, in a well-lit environment, the leaves robustly develop a thicker constitution. A particularly distinguishing feature of this cultivar is the exquisite maroon margin it develops when exposed to bright light.
ㅤ
It is crucial to understand that the morphology of the leaves can be significantly influenced by environmental factors. Therefore, the appearance of your plant may diverge from the mature specimens depicted in photographs. Environmental conditions play a substantial role in shaping the plant's physical characteristics.
ㅤ
I wholeheartedly endorse this cultivar to all Hoya enthusiasts, whether you're a beginner or a seasoned collector. Its visually arresting appearance coupled with its responsive growth patterns make it an intriguing and rewarding addition to any Hoya collection. For optimal cultivation, I strongly recommend situating the plant in an environment with bright, yet shaded, light. Doing so will not only allow the plant to flourish but also accentuate its unique features, thereby offering a gratifying horticultural experience.
ㅤ
Please note that there are multiple varieties in the market named Hoya (Patcharawalai seedling). Since these don't have an official name, they could all be different clones.
ㅤ
#Hoyapatcharawalaiseedling

So here's the backstory: I spotted this lone vine with these almost magical silver leaves. I let it do its thing, watched it closely, and once it looked steady, I went snip-snip and started propagating. Dive into a green adventure with the charming Hoya sp. IV from WMZ, a rare find rooted in the flourishing botanical haven of the Welsh Mountain Zoo. Nestled in the scenic vistas of Northern Wales, UK, WMZ opens up a 37-acre garden wonderland, the birthplace of this delightful Hoya species.
ㅤ
Now, let's talk about the cool stuff that makes this cultivar a standout. The leaves—oh, they go big with a little support and a shady spot to chill in. But give them a dose of bright light, and they turn up the drama by flaunting shades of bright red to maroon, with the green veins playing a cool contrast. It’s like having a color-changing companion right in your space!
ㅤ
And here’s where it gets even more exciting—the flowers. They’re not just your everyday blooms. They’ve got this unique trait of changing colors thanks to anthocyanins, the cool pigments that also jazz up the leaf colors. Under low light, the flowers are almost like soft whispers in white. But let them bask in bright light, and boom, they burst into a beautiful shade of pink. It’s like having a little garden party every time the light changes.
ㅤ
Oh, and the scent? It’s a light, perfume-like aroma that’s just oh-so-inviting. Whenever our plants are in bloom, I find myself stopping by for a little sniff. It’s like a little burst of positivity that makes the day shine a little brighter!
ㅤ
Whether you’re a long-time plant buddy or just starting to dip your toes into the green world, the Hoya sp. IV from WMZ is more than just a plant. It’s a conversation starter, a mood lifter, and a sweet scented companion that brings along a rich tale from one of the UK’s beloved zoological gardens. So, ready to add a touch of whimsical botanical heritage to your collection?
ㅤ
#HoyaspIVfromWMZ

Let's take a moment to digest this new information: Several Hoyas will now be grouped under the name "Hoya ischnopus." Specifically:
ㅤ
- Hoya montana
- Hoya dischorensis
- Hoya dimorpha
- Hoya kenejiana
- Hoya flavescens
ㅤ
While there might be more to come, these are the ones being lumped together for now.
ㅤ
I understand that this reclassification might be a bit frustrating. After all, it's not the first time we've seen Hoyas we know and love combined into one name. But, in my opinion, it's actually a constructive move. It not only simplifies care but also brings clarity to our understanding of these plants.
ㅤ
Here's the reasoning: Original classifications separated these plants based on how they adapted to different geographical areas. With new research, however, we're learning that they're essentially the same plant, just exhibiting different adaptations due to their environment. Hence, this umbrella term should make it easier for us to take care of them.
ㅤ
What's your take on this? Would you like me to delve into more details?
ㅤ
This post was prompted by a facebook post made by Kate Fredericksen. If you're on facebook, join the group "Hoya Identification" to stay in the loop with the community. It's a wonderful community to be in!
ㅤ
#HoyaNameChange

🌱 Introducing the Hoya darwinii with its Gorgeous Pink Flowers! 🌸
ㅤ
Guys, I have to share this triumph with you! Meet my Hoya darwinii, one of the most challenging Hoyas I've ever tried to grow. I'll be honest, I've lost a few of these in the past and was about to throw in the trowel. 😅 But then, during a recent peduncle hunt in the greenhouse, guess what I found? Not only is this beauty alive, it's flourishing! 🎉
ㅤ
🌿 Personal Care Insights: Drawing from my own journey with these plants, let me tell you, the care for Hoya darwinii closely resembles that of Hoya undulata. While there's a widespread belief that Hoya undulata is tough to care for, that hasn't been my experience. The tricky part usually comes right after you've imported the plant or are in the middle of the rooting process. Once you get past that stage, this plant is surprisingly forgiving—whether you overwater or underwater it a bit, it just keeps on growing. The secret sauce? Good aeration and a warm environment. 🌡️ So yes, I can definitely attest to this; once they're settled, they're pretty easygoing!
ㅤ
We've just recently propagated our Hoya darwinii and will continue to study how it adapts to various conditions. This is to help me give you more precise care tips, especially if you're thinking of adding one to your collection. Because trust me, these pink blooms are *so worth your time*! 🌸
ㅤ
Do you have a Hoya darwinii in your collection? What's been your experience? I'd love to hear your thoughts! 💬
ㅤ
#HoyaDarwiniipink
ㅤ

🌸 New Blooms Alert: The Evolving Shades of Hoya lacunosa (purple) 🌸
ㅤ
Hey plant lovers, take a look at these freshly bloomed Hoya lacunosa flowers. Fun fact: they start off white and gradually shift to a pinkish-purple hue. Spotted the transformation this morning and thought it was too cool not to share.
ㅤ
🌞 Bright and Happy: This particular plant is thriving in our well-lit greenhouse where the humidity ranges between 40-50%. It's placed near the ceiling, so it's getting plenty of light.
ㅤ
💦 Watering Routine: Given its size and root-bound nature, we water it every two days. Currently, it's housed in a 6-inch hanging pot and potted in a pure coco husk mix. This helps ensure the soil doesn't stay wet for too long and provides good aeration.
ㅤ

Happy New Year, plant enthusiasts! 🎉 I trust you all had a splendid holiday season. Apologies for the radio silence; it was time well spent recharging with family. But now, let's dive back into the world of Hoya love and care!
ㅤ
Recently, I received an intriguing question from Tori (@plantmomtori) via DM, struggling with mysterious dark fungal spots on her Hoya heuschkeliana. It's a scenario I've encountered through my own trials and tribulations with these plants. After much observation, it seems certain Hoyas are just more sensitive to temperature drops, and Hoya heuschkeliana is particularly susceptible. Despite my deep dive into the exact fungus or bacteria responsible, the culprit remains elusive. However, fear not! This issue hasn't spread to other plants or caused any fatal damage to the Hoya heuschkeliana.
ㅤ
For those of you nurturing this particular Hoya, I hope this insight eases your concerns during the chilly season! 🌿
ㅤ
Now, let's turn it into a community discussion: What other Hoyas in your collection are sensitive to the cold? I'll go first with the Hoya incrassata.
ㅤ

Let's dive into the world of Hoya anulata (NS05-055), a delightful variant of the well-loved Hoya anulata, discovered in the Oro Province of Papua New Guinea by the renowned Nathalie Caowynn Juhonewe. This particular clone, previously known as Hoya sp. NS05-055, has carved out a special place in my collection. It's not the fastest grower, but its slower pace is a blessing in disguise, allowing me to appreciate its stunning transformations. In bright environments, the leaves adopt lovely pink hues, a visual treat that's enhanced by the ample light. For those who favor a more subdued elegance, lower light conditions retain its leaves' dark green allure. I've found that ample light not only accentuates its color but also encourages the production of peduncles, leading to more frequent and bountiful blooms. And speaking of blooms, they are a sight to behold! Not only visually striking, but these flowers also emit a sweet, fresh coconut fragrance, adding a sensory delight to their visual beauty.
ㅤ
Growing Hoya anulata (NS05-055) in a hanging pot accentuates its beauty, as its growth habit is more upright than trailing, presenting its magnificent blooms and colorful leaves like a cascading bouquet. This Hoya is a testament to the wonders of patient cultivation, offering both aesthetic and olfactory pleasures while teaching us the value of understanding and catering to a plant's unique environmental preferences.
ㅤ
#Hoyaspns05055
#Hoyaanulata

Hoya undulata (clone 2) 

Have you given a home to the stunning Hoya undulata yet? If not, what’s holding you back? Maybe 2024 is the year you add this gem to your green family!

Here’s the scoop: Our Hoya undulatas are living their best life in a sun-kissed greenhouse, basking in that sweet spot of 50-60% humidity. This VIP treatment means their leaves are thick, lush, and the colors? Absolutely drool-worthy. Water-wise, let’s just say they’ve been more ‘free-spirited’ until recently. I’ve finally looped them into our irrigation system because, honestly, losing one would be a heartbreaker. Plus, they’ve gotten all cozy and entwined with the greenhouse structure – who’s got the heart to disturb that plant cuddle-fest?

Embark on a botanical journey with Hoya trigonolobos, a lush beauty discovered by Rudolf Schlechter in 1905 and native to the Philippines. 🌿 Fun fact: While it’s commonly misspelled as ‘trigonolobus’, the correct spelling is ‘trigonolobos’ – and yes, I’ve made that typo too! 😩 Its delicate, pale yellow blooms are a sight to behold in shady, humid environments. More than just a plant, it’s a living slice of history. 🌟
